name: Kulcha
history: Kulcha is a type of leavened flatbread that originates from the Indian subcontinent. It's particularly popular in North India and is often enjoyed with chole (spiced chickpeas) or other curries.
description: Kulcha is a soft, fluffy bread made from refined flour and leavened with yeast or baking powder. It's often flavored with spices or stuffed with fillings like spiced potatoes or paneer. Kulcha is traditionally baked in a tandoor but can be cooked on a griddle.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine all-purpose flour, baking powder, baking soda, sugar, and salt. Add yogurt, milk, and oil, and knead into a soft dough. Cover and let it rest for 1-2 hours.

instructions.title: Roll the Kulchas
instructions.description: Divide the dough into equal portions. Roll each portion into a flat circle. Sprinkle sesame seeds and chopped cilantro on top and roll again to press them into the dough.

instructions.title: Cook the Kulchas
instructions.description: Heat a tawa or skillet. Place a rolled kulcha on it and cook until bubbles appear. Flip and cook the other side until golden brown spots appear. Brush with butter or ghee.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the kulchas hot with curry, dal, or any other side dish.

tips: Ensure the dough is soft and well-rested for fluffy kulchas.
Cook on medium heat to avoid burning while ensuring thorough cooking.
variations: Stuff with spiced potato or paneer mixture for a filling meal.
Add garlic or herbs to the dough for additional flavors.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh but can be stored in an airtight container for up to 24 hours.
storage.instructions: Reheat on a skillet before serving if stored.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on a hot skillet or tawa until warm and soft.
presentationTips: Serve in a basket lined with a cloth to keep them warm.
Pair with a variety of chutneys and dips for a complete meal.
